docs.title: SuperStack
docs.text:
Jump to: GitHub | Developer Wiki

SuperStack is a minimal, modular backend powered by Docker — perfect for indie developers, SaaS builders, and teams who want full control without the bloat.

Spin up a fully working backend in seconds. Just clone, run, and start building.

docs.title: 🚀 What Can I Do with SuperStack?
docs.text:
It's perfect for:

  • 🧱 Building SaaS apps
  • 💻 Running multiple stacks
  • 📦 Easy database migrations
  • 🔧 Customizing your toolchain

Everything runs inside Docker and routes through a single exposed port (via Caddy), making it easy to develop locally or deploy remotely.

docs.title: ☁️ Deploying to Remote Environments
docs.text: SuperStack is Docker-native, so deployments are simple, consistent, and portable. The goal is that only compose.yaml and secrets need to exist on the remote server.

docs.title: 🧱 1. Build Your Images
docs.text:
If a service has a build: section, add your own image name and version tag:

compose.yaml
services:
  caddy:
    build:
      context: ./caddy
    image: ghcr.io/youruser/yourapp-caddy:0.1.0

Build and push your images:

docker compose build
docker compose push

docs.title: 📦 2. Copy to Server
docs.text:
Copy your compose.yaml to the remote host:

scp compose.yaml youruser@yourserver:

docs.title: 3. Set Secrets
docs.text:
Your app will need credentials such as database passwords or API keys. Choose one of these approaches:

  1. .env file — simplest for manual deploys.
chmod 600 .env
  1. Environment variables — pass them directly to the command line.
  2. CI/CD injection — good for automated pipelines.

docs.title: 🚀 Launch the App
docs.text:
Start the application on the server:

docker compose pull
docker compose up -d

Your backend is now live. 🚀

docs.title: 🧭 Next Steps
docs.text:
This setup replaces the stack in place.

If you want zero-downtime deployments, rollback support, or blue-green testing, see the Wiki page: Advanced Deployments.

docs.title: 🚀 Getting Started
docs.text: SuperStack uses Docker, so make sure Docker is installed before you begin.

docs.title: Option 1: Use the Template (Easiest)
docs.text:
Click Use this template and create a new repository (e.g. myapp-backend) on GitHub.

Clone it to your machine:

git clone https://github.com/yourname/myapp-backend.git
cd myapp-backend

docs.title: Option 2: Clone and Track Upstream (Advanced)
docs.text:
If you want to keep SuperStack’s Git history and pull upstream changes later, clone SuperStack:

git clone https://github.com/explodinglabs/superstack.git myapp-backend
cd myapp-backend

Create your own repo, then:

git remote rename origin upstream
git remote add origin https://github.com/yourname/myapp-backend.git
git push -u origin main

You can now pull upstream changes with:

git pull upstream main

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment Variables
docs.text:
Copy the example environment file:

cd app
cp example.env .env

The .env file is used to set secrets, passwords, keys, etc.

⚠️ Never store secrets in version control.

docs.title: 3. Start the App
docs.text:
docker compose up -d

That's it – your backend is live.

Test it with:

$ curl http://localhost:8000/healthcheck
OK
